statement.text: The de Broglie wavelength is the quantum mechanical wavelength associated with any particle, inversely proportional to its momentum. It represents the wave nature of matter predicted by quantum mechanics, with λ_dB = h/p for a particle with momentum p. Unlike the Compton wavelength which depends on rest mass, the de Broglie wavelength depends on the particle's motion.
statement.formal: λ_dB = h/p = h/(mv) = ℏ/(mv) · (2π) for particle with momentum p = mv
statement.value: For electron at v = 10⁶ m/s: λ_dB ≈ 0.73 nm; depends on velocity
statement.formula_unicode: λ_dB = h/p = h/(mv), or λ_dB = ℏ/(mv) · (2π)

explanation.intuition: Every moving object has a wavelength! For a baseball (m ~ 0.15 kg) thrown at 40 m/s, λ_dB = h/(mv) ~ 10⁻³⁴ m - far too small to ever detect. But for an electron (m = 9.1×10⁻³¹ kg) moving at 10⁶ m/s, λ_dB ~ 0.7 nm - comparable to atomic spacing! This is why electron diffraction works: electrons behave as waves when passing through crystals. The faster the particle moves, the shorter its wavelength (λ_dB ∝ 1/v). The heavier the particle, the shorter its wavelength (λ_dB ∝ 1/m). Only for light, low-momentum particles do quantum wave effects become visible.
explanation.key_insight: The de Broglie wavelength λ_dB = h/p is fundamentally different from the Compton wavelength λ_C = h/(mc)! Compton wavelength depends on rest mass m and is intrinsic to the particle. De Broglie wavelength depends on momentum p = mv and changes with velocity. For a stationary particle (v=0), λ_dB → ∞ (infinite wavelength). For a particle moving at speed c (photons), λ_dB = h/(mc) reduces to the photon wavelength λ = hc/E. The relationship to Compton wavelength is: λ_dB/λ_C = mc/(mv) = c/v. So λ_dB = λ_C only when v = c! At low velocities v << c, de Broglie wavelength is much larger than Compton wavelength. At relativistic speeds v ~ c, they become comparable. For Planck momentum p_P = m_P c = √(ℏc/G)·c, the de Broglie wavelength is λ_dB(p_P) = h/p_P = h/(m_P c) = 2πℏ/(m_P c) = 2πℓ_P (full wavelength) or λ_dB = ℓ_P (reduced wavelength using ℏ).
explanation.technical_details: De Broglie wavelength (full): λ_dB = h/p = h/(mv). Using reduced Planck constant: λ_dB = 2πℏ/p = 2πℏ/(mv). For non-relativistic particles: p = mv, so λ_dB = h/(mv). For relativistic particles: p = γmv where γ = 1/√(1-v²/c²), so λ_dB = h/(γmv). For photons (m=0): p = E/c = hf/c, so λ = c/f = h/p (recovers photon wavelength). Examples: Electron at 1 eV kinetic energy: v ≈ 5.9×10⁵ m/s, λ_dB ≈ 1.2 nm (comparable to atomic spacing). Electron at 100 eV: λ_dB ≈ 0.12 nm (X-ray scale). Neutron at room temperature (kT ~ 25 meV): λ_dB ≈ 0.18 nm (neutron diffraction). At Planck momentum p_P = m_P c: λ_dB = h/(m_P c) = 2πℏ/(m_P c) = 2π·(ℏ/(m_P c)) = 2πℓ_P ≈ 10⁻³⁴ m. Electron microscopy: accelerating electrons to 100 keV gives λ_dB ≈ 0.004 nm (resolves atomic structure). Matter wave experiments: C₆₀ molecules (60 carbon atoms!) show interference with λ_dB ~ picometers.
common_misconceptions: de Broglie wavelength is NOT the same as Compton wavelength - different formulas!
λ_dB = h/p depends on momentum (motion); λ_C = h/(mc) depends on rest mass
de Broglie wavelength is NOT the 'size' of the particle - it's a wave property
λ_dB is NOT constant for a particle - it changes with velocity!
For stationary particles (v=0), λ_dB → ∞, not zero
Baseball wavelength is NOT zero - it's just immeasurably small (~10⁻³⁴ m)
Photons do NOT have Compton wavelength (m=0) but do have de Broglie wavelength

definition.@value: The de Broglie wavelength λ_dB = h/p is the quantum mechanical wavelength associated with a particle of momentum p, representing the wave nature of matter. It is inversely proportional to momentum and depends on the particle's velocity.

scopeNote.@value: Used in quantum mechanics, electron microscopy, neutron diffraction, matter wave interference, and understanding wave-particle duality. Critical for understanding electron and neutron scattering experiments.
